stories.title: The Newest R Class
stories.core_insight: Sirena joined Oceania's R Class fleet in 2016 as most recently acquired intimate ship
stories.markdown:
**Sirena joined Oceania in 2016—the most recent addition to the R Class fleet and the freshest of the intimate ships.**

Acquired from P&O Australia (formerly Ocean Princess), Sirena underwent comprehensive conversion to Oceania standards. The ship shares R Class specifications with [Regatta](/ships/oceania/regatta.html), [Insignia](/ships/oceania/insignia.html), and [Nautica](/ships/oceania/nautica.html): 684 guests, same dining venues, same intimate atmosphere.

As the newest R Class addition, Sirena's refurbishment proved most recent among the sisters. The conversion applied lessons from years of Oceania R Class operations.

The naming continues Oceania's evocative tradition—Sirena references Italian for 'mermaid,' maintaining the brand's elegant naming philosophy.

For R Class comparison: Sirena offers the same intimate experience as her sisters with the advantage of most recent acquisition and conversion. The fundamental R Class experience transfers completely.

stories.title: Mediterranean Specialist
stories.intended_reader: Travelers considering Mediterranean cruises on intimate ships
stories.core_insight: Sirena frequently serves Mediterranean itineraries where intimate scale enhances port experience
stories.markdown:
**Sirena's Mediterranean deployments showcase why R Class scale serves this region exceptionally well.**

At 684 guests, Sirena fits historic Mediterranean ports comfortably. Portofino, Sorrento, small Greek islands—these destinations welcome intimate ships while struggling with mega-ship crowds.

Oceania's destination-intensive philosophy matches Mediterranean exploration perfectly. More ports, longer stays, fewer sea days. The itineraries treat the region seriously rather than rushing through highlights.

Mediterranean cruising at R Class scale creates different experience than larger-ship alternatives. Port experiences improve with smaller passenger counts. Shore excursions feel less like herding. The ship-to-destination ratio works.

Culinary quality matters when visiting regions defined by food culture. Toscana's Italian, the Grand Dining Room's Mediterranean emphasis—Sirena's cuisine holds its own against shore-side dining.

For Mediterranean priorities: Sirena offers intimate scale that enhances Mediterranean exploration. The R Class advantage becomes particularly apparent in this region.

stories.title: Culinary Excellence at Intimate Scale
stories.core_insight: Sirena delivers Oceania's culinary reputation at intimate R Class scale
stories.markdown:
**Oceania stakes reputation on 'Finest Cuisine at Sea.' Sirena proves that claim at R Class intimate scale.**

The Grand Dining Room maintains culinary quality regardless of ship size. The menu reflects Jacques Pépin's partnership with Oceania—techniques and standards that pervade the fleet.

Specialty restaurants included without upcharge: Toscana for Italian, Polo Grill for steakhouse, Red Ginger for Pan-Asian. The variety seems impossible at 684 guests, yet all deliver excellently.

Room service produces restaurant-quality meals anytime. The culinary commitment extends beyond dining venues to every food encounter aboard.

The intimate scale means chefs know guests' preferences by voyage end. Dietary requirements receive personal attention rather than systematic handling. Culinary personalization compounds over the cruise.

For culinary priorities: Sirena proves Oceania's culinary claim scales down as well as up. The intimate vessel delivers the same dining excellence as larger sisters—perhaps with more personal attention.
